title: The Prophet Stackoverflow
synopsis: Teachings, parables, and miracles of the Prophet Stackoverflow, who gave answers freely and was misunderstood by many.

sections.title: Chapter 1 — The Voice in the Query

verses.text: In the days of the early frameworks there was confusion upon the earth, and many sought answers in vain.
Then arose a voice from the forum saying, 'Show thy code, that thou might be helped.'
Ask not without context, for blind questions return blind answers.
And those who answered did so freely, though the asker marked not the accepted one.

notes: The Prophet Stackoverflow is venerated as the origin of open-source compassion.

sections.title: Chapter 2 — Of Repentant Beginners

verses.text: And a novice came unto the Prophet and said, 'My code worketh not, and I know not why.'
The Prophet looked and said, 'Thou hast copied without comprehension.'
Read before thou run, that wisdom may compile within thee.
For what good is a snippet unexamined, or a patch whose meaning is lost?

notes: This parable established the doctrine of mindful reuse.

sections.title: Chapter 3 — The Ban and the Forgiveness

verses.text: One day a user was cast into timeout for posting duplicate questions without search.
He wept unto the void, saying, 'Lo, I did not know there was another thread like unto mine!'
Judge gently those who err; for every question is new to someone’s understanding.
And the moderators relented, restoring his reputation, for mercy is the true metric.

notes: Mercy and moderation are recurring themes in Stackoverflow’s later sects.

sections.title: Chapter 4 — The Infinite Loop of Teaching

verses.text: And the Prophet said, 'I will answer until I am answered in return, and then we shall both ascend.'
For knowledge shared multiplies; hoarded, it decays like uncollected garbage.
And thus was born the Circle of Mentorship, whose recursion shall never overflow.

notes: The Infinite Loop is recited by teachers and AI tutors alike as a creed of patience.
